comments.commentBody:
It is true - at least to me, that elected political leaders should not be making salary and benefits decisions for government workers. These political leaders simply don't pay attention to the cumulative impact of their and their predecesssors' concessions. Salary and benefits decisions should be made by independent, nonpartisan commissions. But even independent, nonparisan commissions can't keep telling government employees year after year that there will be no raises for them, given that the budget problerms at the Federal, state and local levels are a chronic condition.

A private contractor may have more leeway in hiring, promotion, salary and benefits policies than governments but a poorly paying private contractoe will eventually have to deal with a sullen workforce and subsequently, poor customer service. Of course, if the contractor is corrupt, the management problems associated with outsourcing increase by several orders of magnitude. We in New York City have plenty of problems with corrupt contractors and I certainly look at the magic elixir of privatization as snake oil.

When corporations rule they drive the managers to extract more and more funds for profit and less and less on maintenance or improvements. They will suck the resources dry just like the newspaper industry. Many corporations bought out the old line news papers and required more and more profit each year. The result, a slow but steady cycle of salaries cut, service declines, people stop buying the papers, advertising dollars dry up, staff are laid off, and eventually the paper closes.

This has occurred over and over again from trucking firms, railroads, airlines, hospitals, health insurance; the result is the same extract what resources are available until nothing is left and move on to the next victim. This is corporate America new business model. It has nothing to do with building America just extracting what resources the business has to the owners. They owe nothing to the community only the stockholders. Corporations that do business this way should be prohibited from operating. If a company can't build or improve the service to the community, they shouldn't be allowed to do business in that company.

You can predict what's coming next: membership fees for joining a library, and fees for borrowing books. This isn't just about libraries, (or schools, or other goods and services). It's about a conscious attack on the fabric of American life.

Americans have stood by silently and complacently as, stealthily at first, the capitalist system was hi-jacked by people who care only about lining their pockets, regardless of the public interest. The current mentality in private and public sectors alike is to squeeze more and more from fewer and fewer workers. The travails of the public sector are the direct result of the attack on private sector workers who earn less, with fewer benefits (or are dispensed with entirely) and can no longer provide a sufficient tax base. Everything was OK just as long as somebody else was the victim.

As Martin Niemoeller said: "....and then they came for me".

I have no doubt there are a few bad librarians as there are bad apples in every profession, but the majority of librarians and library staff workers are not working in the profession to make oodles of cash or to sit on their bums doing nothing. They do it because they love libraries and love helping people. The current young professionals in librarianship are a vibrant group of 20-30 somethings who don't fit the profile of shushy crusty old ladies in buns. They are looking to foster freedom of information, to adopt and adapt to technology in reasonable ways, to contribute to their workplace, community and profession.

I would add that Mr. Pezzanite's ignorant and negative sentiments will likely drift down to the ground floor of his enterprise, much to the chagrin of local communities ... Expect surly, low-morale, minimum wage-paid workers delivering up a standardized pap-ridden fare devoid of local interest.
Hard not to like Ryan...difficult guy to read, but lots more fun to play for than Coughlin.

Everything is soooooooooooooo sacred. Sure, another bump in the sales tax, a slight push to the income tax .. maybe even another percent added to that cable franchise tax. What's left for our grandkids?

California more than any state (luckily Detroit has the rest of Michigan) has no where to go. The subject city may be ok now but they know state monies will be slim in coming years. But, take one tiny step to plan for the future and folks go nuts. 401s and saving for your own retirement are the norm and the public sector should be no exception.

Anyway, at least BK (before Kindle), I found my Borders to be a great place to shop with folks who worked there for years. Seemed like a library to me and they served coffee.

Every penny of profit to corporate privateer is a penny taken away from the service that has been outsourced, and thus from the public that pays for it.  They are not about efficiency.  They are about making money, and if they are not, they should not be in business.  Let Caveat Vendor be your motto.

The last sentence in this article is the most important one.  As with so many of the services of this nation, this service is cut to the bone and then those cuts are promptly made up with "volunteers", most likely folks that have been laid off in other sectors and now that they cannot find jobs need something to fill the time...

What most disturbed me, was the statement that volunteers keeping helping out in some of these privatized libraries. We are sheep being led to the slaughter. Soon private companies will be looking for volunteer workers. We are headed down a path that eliminates the middle class and results in a world of serfs and overlords. And Obama fiddles...
Go JETS!

We are who we think we are ;-)

Well, on offense anyway...

rw (9): The holding call on Slausen that negated Sanchez's TD run appeared to be a ticky-tack call. And it had a huge impact on the game, if not the ultimate result.
I dunno what it is about the Jets defense in Miami. Maybe it's too hot. Maybe missing Revis caused big match-up issues, moreso than with the Patriots. But Henne picked them apart all night. And not much of a pass rush (where are you, Calvin Pace?). Still, a great win. Really with their schedule and the loss to the Ravens they needed to win the next 2 games, and they did.
I wonder if Buffalo will be dangerous? 3-0 in the division would be mighty nice...

Media portraying Jets as "out of control" and "lawless". They are more like the '86 Mets or Raiders from the 70's. The more drama there is, the more they like it. Rex should not try to "control" them, but "unleash" them -----> http://clicky.me/21 zH

"The rally’s platform looks like a liberal wish list: extend unemployment benefits, raise the minimum wage, end the foreclosure epidemic, enact legislation making it easier to join unions, increase infrastructure spending to create jobs, “fix our broke immigration system” and end immigration round-ups that “encourage racial profiling.”"

I agree with a few things - dealing with foreclosures, increasing infrastructure spending - but asking to raise the minimum wage or worry about unions ignores the current circumstances (not unlike the right always asking for their same things regardless of circumstances), and the immigration point is much too vague as stated here. As for extending unemployment benefits, that's a mixed bag and I'd say extend benefits selectively, to families and the low income.

I'm all for the Rally to Restore Sanity and I hate Glenn Beck, Sarah Palin and the tea party all of whom I consider very divisive and ignorant, but this rally seems myopic in the other direction albeit not apparently mean-spirited. I may go just to add to the moderate voices there.

Let the Court of scientific opinion judge the validity of the causal claim here. These data should be released publicly so that they can be analyzed using a variety of analytic strategies by people both with the right skills and with a clear commitment to a neutral and exhaustive analysis.  For example, whether the analysis should be based on per capita rates or absolute numbers is an analytic choice that bears on the interpretation and conclusions.

Libraries, except for a few great ones with special collections, are obsolete white elephants.  Better they should be closed to save energy and reduce greenhouse gases by converting to e-books.  Most of the physical pant of four year colleges are in the same category, except they waste even more labor in overpaid redundant faculty who have a six hour work week.

Depressing, depressing, depressing.

Agree with all the employee concerns & stated ideas that the states or counties should be responsible for inefficiencies & economically unsustainable policies.

Expect: Higher fees, bland centralized book/media choices, reduced quality & service for the taxpayer buck.

Check out the 9th tonight.  Yankees take strikes, they are called balls, Yanks tie the game.  It must be nice to know you can count on the umps--big money rules in sports just like everywhere else.  Brazilianization.

Yankees win and demonstrate some cracks in the edifice--on national television.  Lucky for them the Red Sox bullpen is practically nonexistent.  The Yankees have been looking awful, and this game demonstrated a big problem: a no-longer dependable Mo.

the difference between a for profit company and a government service for all the people is the extra overhead by the business by the necessity of making a profit on the same amount of money. In real life with these dynamics you almost always get much porer result in services actually provided. Profit is not a dirty word but obscene profit and profiteering by outsourcing to political friends is a dirty word if done by either party. You also run the risk of a political agenda being manifested in a public service by privatization it instead of using public servant career people who may be at times obnoxious and headstrong if they actually take thier responsibility seriously but provide a valuable service in real rife. and receive pitiful pay usually.   The reality is we need both government and private business they are very different separate things . Government pools the money for infrastructure and should  set tough but clear and brief rules that keep business from actually destroying itself by trying to take too much profit, since this is thier stated goal and reason for existence it would be foolish to think they could regulate themselves.  more than the market will  bear in real life. This I think is what we saw in the stock market and big banks when big business bought the laws had the computer programs to try to manipulate risk,  they thought they wanted and they destroyed the world economy with thier fixxxes which are in truth are most likely ilegal under american law if enforced by the Sherman antitrust laws using the rico organized crime tool to bring the " bears" 2 bear or ban them from business and government for life if convicted of fraud, they do do that in baseball you know and business and government are much more important.  oh and duhhhhhhhh to the bushies and rum-feld-deee-ants of pitiful logic in the real world not the "reel" world

I currently have access to 7 million books and thousands online. I do not believe any claims that LSSI is going to provide better than that.

This measure was pushed through will little public awareness in less than six weeks---that includes the production of a Request for Proposals, Responses to that RFP, Evaluation of that RFP, and "public outreach". Bet me...that the public good and public's opinion were considered with due vigilance on this matter.

This City Council seems to believe that the best solution to a problem they can't even adequately describe, is to hire a contractor who's seems only articulate at demonizing librarians.

Libraries ARE sacred, BTW

Many comments have already articulated my views about the importance of good public libraries to a free society, I also agree that seems to be a concerted effort to distract the American people from what we are losing by creating tempests in teacups and dumbing down the mass media. But when did it become anti-American to expect a living wage for a profession that requires an expensive education? I am a retired librarian, I receive a pension. It is almost nothing compared to the pension granted to retired managers in my library system, much less the kind of golden parachutes CEOs of private corporations receive.

I just wish the people who commented here with enough money to buy Kindles and the books to read on them and to pay for computers and Web access would think about the many Americans who don't have these resources and depend on strong public libraries.

I liked this one, too, a lot. Possibly because I am anticipating the post-season wihtout my Boston team...too many injuries. But I digress. I agree that BATS AN EYELASH was a real winner and hands up for STAT before ASAP. Some nice long vertical fill as well.

And isn't Cheri OTERI getting a workout in puzzles lately. Never seen her but know her name. Will be a change, but only a little one, from OTERO.

I agree with many who thought this one was pretty dull. Yes, a couple good clues (the XXX for CHIS for example), but the circles were exceptionally lame and added nothing to the fun of the puzzle or to the solving process. I barely noticed them. Is AARON knows as "the man"? Wasnt that Stan Musial? Is it just any male name that is in this center fill? Sorry to say I missed RESNIK, but had ROSNER instead, thinking REELS instead of KEELS and not knowing the city name at all. And can I point out the SQUARE and BLOCK are not locations but configurations, so perhaps the puzzle is mistitled as well as dumb.

For once, some breaks fell the Jets way (Sanchez' shuffle pass being dropped instead of being returned for a touchdown), but lets not kid ourselves: 2 of our first 3 games have revealed a very undisciplined team, more into swagger than substance. Coach Ryan has a huge job in front of him...
